title: 1311-D
statement: D. Three Integerstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given three integers $$$a \\le b \\le c$$$.In one move, you can add $$$+1$$$ or $$$-1$$$ toanyof these integers (i.e. increase or decrease any number by one). You can perform such operation any (possibly, zero) number of times, you can even perform this operation several times with one number.Note that you cannot make non-positive numbers using such operations.You have to perform the minimum number of such operations in order to obtain three integers $$$A \\le B \\le C$$$ such that $$$B$$$ is divisible by $$$A$$$ and $$$C$$$ is divisible by $$$B$$$.You have to answer $$$t$$$ independent test cases.InputThe first line of the input contains one integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 100$$$) — the number of test cases.The next $$$t$$$ lines describe test cases. Each test case is given on a separate line as three space-separated integers $$$a, b$$$ and $$$c$$$ ($$$1 \\le a \\le b \\le c \\le 10^4$$$).OutputFor each test case, print the answer. In the first line print $$$res$$$ — the minimum number of operations you have to perform to obtain three integers $$$A \\le B \\le C$$$ such that $$$B$$$ is divisible by $$$A$$$ and $$$C$$$ is divisible by $$$B$$$. On the second line printanysuitable triple $$$A, B$$$ and $$$C$$$.ExampleInput8 1 2 3 123 321 456 5 10 15 15 18 21 100 100 101 1 22 29 3 19 38 6 30 46Output1 1 1 3 102 114 228 456 4 4 8 16 6 18 18 18 1 100 100 100 7 1 22 22 2 1 19 38 8 6 24 48

processed.result:
You are given three integers $a \le b \le c$. You can add or subtract 1 from any of these integers any number of times.  You cannot make any of the numbers non-positive.

Find the minimum number of operations needed to make the following true:

* $b$ is divisible by $a$
* $c$ is divisible by $b$

You need to solve this problem for multiple sets of three integers.

You are given three numbers. You can increase or decrease each number by 1 any number of times.  Find the fewest changes needed to make the middle number divide evenly into the first number, and the largest number divide evenly into the middle number.
